titleInfo.title: Map of the field of Shiloh, near Pittsburgh Landing, Tenn.

mods.abstract: This map includes federal troop positions for Grant's Army of the Tennessee and Buell's Army of the Ohio for the morning and evenings of April 6 and April 7. The various creeks, roads, homes, hospitals, Shiloh Church, the cotton press, Pittsburgh Landing, and the gunboats Tyler and Lexington are all included.

After successive defeats in northern Tennessee, the Confederate army regrouped in Corinth, Mississippi, under Generals Albert Sidney Johnston and P. G. T. Beauregard, as the Army of Mississippi. On April 6, 1862, it made a surprise attack on the Unionâ€™s Army of the Tennessee under the command of General Ulysses S. Grant at Pittsburg Landing, Tennessee. Later known as the Battle of Shiloh, this was deadliest battle in American history up to that date. The surprise paid off initially, as Union troops were put on the defensive. However, the arrival of Union General Don Carlos Buell proved to be the turning point as the Confederate forces were routed, amassing over ten thousand casualties.
